intro: Taeniophyllum erinaceum, commonly known as the hairy bladderwort, is a small, aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. It is characterized by its tiny, bladder-like structures called bladders, which it uses to trap small aquatic organisms. The plant is typically found in still or slow-moving freshwater habitats, such as ponds and ditches. It has slender, branching stems and small, scale-like leaves that help reduce water resistance. Taeniophyllum erinaceum is a carnivorous plant, relying on its bladders to supplement its nutrient intake in nutrient-poor environments.
